properties.name: A City Dedicated to Commerce!
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThe City of Commerce was incorporated as a clever tax dodge by the business owners in an unincorporated part of Imaginary County. In their early years, they boasted that their Lacuna Towers were "the tallest buildings east of the LA River and west of the Pomona Valley." They were technically incorrect because building heights include the radio antennas on top, and others had them, but at 18 stories, it was very tall and nobody disputed it. In 1975, crosstown civic rivals, The City of Industry, attempted to steal away the "tallest building" title with their Turnbull Tower, which was 19 stories tall. Commerce retaliated by quietly erecting a 40 foot-tall radio tower on the Lacuna, and hired a Berlin artist to attach illuminated plastic hologram panels to it, so it would resemble a solid, lit structure. They just as quietly stopped mentioning the "tallest building" title when high winds knocked the tower down, into the adjacent electric substation, causing a small fire that cut power to the entire city.

properties.name: ABC Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift This is a post-club nightspot for Asian American kids. The food is pretty weak, but selected dishes are cheap. The G+GOLM isn\'t so good. In fact, it\'s more like chow mein the way it\'s been fried up. You don\'t come here for the food. You come here because some friends said to go here, because it\'s open 24/7.

properties.name: Alfredo's
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftNot that good. Beans were ok, but the cheese was cold. In other words, I\'m going elsewhere. (I got the name wrong - it\'s Alfredo\'s. It\'s still not that good.)

properties.name: Alfredo's
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThis is part of the chain, but it did a lot better than the one in S. El Monte. For one thing, the cheese was melted. The beans were okay too. The only thing is, I don\'t think they really do the B&C, and most people get the meat, because I got the "are you sure?" question. I don\'t think the B&C was even on the menu.

properties.name: Benito's
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift7912 Beverly Blvd, Los Angeles, CANothing special, cold cheese. Possibly fresh beans. It was kind of expensive. It gets the big "hmm... maybe let\'s go to a different place."

properties.name: Beth Israel Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftJewish Cemetery

properties.name: Biker guy got hurt
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI don\'t know why, but I got on the freeway into heavy rush hour traffic, only to see in the median, a leather jacket biker guy who got into some kind of collision with a car or two, and was knocked off. He was bleeding all over the asphalt. the traffic plodded forward, as rubberneckers like me stared at the man, and the people who were fretting around him, having their freakouts. the guy wasn\'t doing so well, and hadn\'t been wearing his leathers, and his body was cut up. the traffic parted to let a fire truck drive in reverse down the freeway to rescue the man. I drove forward, like everyone else, and as the thick traffic loosened up, sped away from the scene, trying to forget, telling myself that this dude was going to be okay.

properties.name: Cactus Taqueria
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftCactus Taqueria, venerable Hollywood and LA stand.

properties.name: Calvary Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftRoman Catholic Cemetery, operated by the Archdiocese.

properties.name: Camry, hit by guy from FSU
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI think it was just before NYE or NYE, but a bunch of us guys were in my Mark\'s car, and another friend, Sam, was driving. We were all sober, except I think I might have had a drink several hours before. It was like a virgin\'s cruise or something. Well, not really, but close. It was pretty late, and as we went through the intersection, the car\'s tail got hit by a frat boy from FSU. We spun out and that was that. I don\'t recall if we had the green, but Sammy said we did. But there were no witnesses, so it was declared that both parties were equally liable.

properties.name: Candace's old Honda gets hit by a Lexus
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftShe\'s making a left onto the 19, and this woman in a Lexus barrels down Huntington and hits the rear of the Honda, spinning it out. The situation seems like a 50/50 liability, or mostly the Lexus\'s fault, but the Lexus driver pulls a fast one and tries to sue. What a low move. As if you\'re going to get money out of someone who owns a Honda with the paint rubbing off.

properties.name: Carl's Jr. / Green Burrito
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftA combo fast food shack, with Carl\'s Jr. *and* The Green Burrito. The GB is allegedly an East LA thing, but, when they started out, it was difficult to believe, because the food was weak. Things have improved.

properties.name: Carson Girls by Angry Samoans
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftIf you\'re thinking about moving West Forget about West L.A. And forget about Torrance baby Cause Carson girls are A-Ok

properties.name: Casa Jimenez
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftAll you can eat food for . Sounds good, but, how many B&C burritos do you really want? Just get one. It wasn\'t exceptional.

properties.name: Catering Truck, name forgotten
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThis is a surprise - some decent food at the catering truck. The B&C is not great, but pretty good for a truck. The mix of cheese and beans is right, but the beans were a little tougher than I like. But I\'m picky.

properties.name: Center for the Revival of Moorish Culture (HISC)
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift The Hispani-Islamic Study Center is the local chapter of the Center for the Revival of Moorish Culture in the Imaginary City metro area. As their name states, they seek to revive aspects of the culture of the Moorish occupation of Spain. Center director Linda Chen has confirmed that the city of Alhambra was chosen as the site because it\'s named after the Alhambra in Spain. In addition to the study center, every third Sunday, they host an open-air food court, where people buy food from Hispani-Islamic booths.

properties.name: Chinese Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThis cemetery was founded in 1922, according ot the linked article.

properties.name: Chinese Potters Field
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftIn 2006, the MTA unearthed a "potter\'s field" or poor-person\'s cemetery, near Evergreen. The probable location of this cemetery was known for a long time, but the MTA didn\'t follow up on comments to the EIR about it. Consequently, during excavation for the Gold Line extension, these bodies were unearthed. For more information see this story: http://www.chssc.org/MTAChineseGraves.html

properties.name: Cinco De Mayo by WAR
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftIt\'s impossible to find the lyrics online, but they have a verse in there: "pretty senorita, down in East LA."

properties.name: DJ Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift 301 E Valley Boulevard, alhambra caNot very good G+GOLM. Salty, dry noodles, and the green onions were overcooked. Ginger was chunky. Soup was cloudy and too rich. This spot is more for hanging out.

properties.name: Del Taco
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift 3020 Los Feliz Blvd, Los Angeles, CA

properties.name: Del Taco
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftFor several years, I was addicted to the Veggie Works burrito. It was a dot-com thing, where I was working so hard, and had to get something to eat at odd hours. Del Taco was open, and the VW was awesome. Now, I\'ve learned that it\'s one of the fattiest, saltiest, and generally least healthy burritos they sell. What\'s up with that? It\'s "veggie." Their chicken burritos are better for you. If you ignore the health factors, the VW is awesome. It\'s got a lot of sour cream and avocado sauce from a can. The beans are so-so.

properties.name: Dos Burritos
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftAdded for completeness, but I can\'t recall what I had. The curtido was surprisingly yummy. Maybe it wasn\'t, but I wasn\'t so critical at the time. I don\'t know. I\'ve had the little B&C bowl thing, and it was okay. The best part about the DB chain is the interior, which they never seem to update. It looks like the 1970s. Los Angeles might be the alternate universe of food, where the food is good, but the interiors are ugly and outdated. It\'s almost like a formula -- if you see it\'s kind of generic decor, but crowded, you know the food is good. (Ever see an empty Zankou Chicken or Sam Woo?) If it looks good inside, and is crowded, there\'s some risk involved. (e.g. PF Changs or any Patina restaurant.) If it\'s attractive and not busy. LOLz. Might as well burn your money, or PayPal it directly to the interior decorator.

properties.name: Doublz
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftLousy. Canned beans were dry and super salty. Cheese was cold. (But I like the fries here.) * Update, I take it back about the fries. I had a lame batch that wasn\'t fried enough. The ones at El Monte were better.

properties.name: Dude with cart, great tacos
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftSeveral years ago, I was coming to this alley to get tacos from some dude with a shopping cart and a circular taco frying grill. Everything was clean and pristine, including the dude, which was good, because the operation was probably illegal. No matters - the tacos were very good, and he had a good, soft tripas (chitlin) taco. Cabbage was slivered well, and the other veggies were prepped well too. Hours seemed to be limited to the early evening to just after dusk.

properties.name: El 7 Mares
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftKnown for great fried fish.

properties.name: El Atacor
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftYes, there\'s another El Atacor down the street. This one seems to be unaffiliated, with it. It seems like there are separate legions of El Atacor shops, and this one is affiliated with one in Pico Rivera (across from Home Depot). Anyway, I did get a B&C here, and it was expensive and small, but memorably good, with molten cheese. It was over , but no larger than the B&C at the top rated J&S. This is a white cheese burrito.

properties.name: El Atacor
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI can\'t give up the 4 stars quite yet. I forgot how good it was, but, it was pretty much runny and melted, and I think they used some kind of white Mexican cheese. Will be trying it again.

properties.name: El Atacor
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI\'m not sure if this is the precise building, but it\'s near here. This is one of two in this area.

properties.name: El Atacor
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThey have a decent B&C, but not as good as the one in LH. I should note that they use white mexican cheese. It\'s unpredictable which cheese any given stand will use. Yellow cheddar is the standard cheese at most "American" stands, or older places, but white seems to be the type at the more "Mexican" places. It\'s one of those things, I guess. At least this stand knew about a B&C. Some of the shops that cater mainly to immigrants don\'t know the B&C, and make mistakes like rolling it up with whole beans and onions (which tastes pretty good, nonetheless).

properties.name: El Atacor
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThis shop is a drive thru, mainly, but the stainless steel bench-and-tables in front are pretty cool. You can see the cars roll down the street, pretty close to your face. I didn\'t get the B&C, so this post isn\'t totally legit, but, I did get a bean tostada. It was a small challenge, because the woman taking the order didn\'t believe I wanted it without meat. (I nibbled on my friend\'s carnitas, and it was good. Maybe people just get meat there.) Anyway, the tostada was okay, but too heavy on the cheese, and too light on the beans. The tortilla was fresh fried.

properties.name: El Pollo Loco
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI wonder what\'s up with EPL. There are a few that are awesome, where you get all this *service* and it\'s really clean, like beyond fast-food. This one isn\'t one of those. They aren\'t that good at keeping the tables clean, or the salsa cold. At least the food tastes ok. The usual order for B&Cers is the BRC, which puts some rice into the mix.

properties.name: El Pollo Loco
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftMexican fast food chain. Specialty is roasted chicken.

properties.name: El Taurino
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThe meat here smells really good. The B&C is good, too, but when you check out the menu and the crowd, it\'s obvious that the vege options are for the vege office worker lunch crowd. The place is reminiscent of King Taco.

properties.name: El Zarape
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI haven\'t had a B&C here in a few years, and my tastes have become more refined. I think it was okay, but don\'t really recall. So it must not have been that good. I\'ll go and check it out again, for this map. They make a decent shrimp coctail, and have good chips. They were the first burrito I had that put a bag of frozen peas-and-carrots into the meat. The restaurant\'s been there around ten years, now, without any radical changes. That\'s a good sign. Also, nearby is Miki Chan\'s, a good quasi-Hawaiian restaurant that\'s had its ups and downs for around 30 years. It\'s having an "up" the past few, with a good owner. They have an awesome Hawaiian chow mein that you\'re not going to find at the other Hawaiian fast food places.

properties.name: Empty Fish Sandwich
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThe fish sandwich plate came out, and it looked pretty good. The onion rings were perfect - just a little oily, crispy all around, and soft inside. The fish however, was overpowered by the American cheese slices, and tasted only of the batter. The fish had no discernable flavor or texture. The bun was soft, but a little too soft. A disappointment.

properties.name: Evergreen Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftEvergreen is the oldest cemetery in the City of Los Angeles. Presently, it is mostly a Japanese American institution, but there are people of all races and creeds buried here. See also: http://www.chssc.org/history/shrinefull.html

properties.name: Everyone likes Guadalajara Brand Taco Sauce
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftVernon, the center of farming and food production in Imaginary County, is known for two things. First is the factory that produces Fisherman Jed\'s marine cuisines. Second is the famous Guadalajara Brand Taco Sauce, with the picture of the mariachi on the bottle.

properties.name: Forest Lawn Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift A very large cemetery, aka "memorial park", with several notable buildings.

properties.name: Got doored, and broke my collarbone.
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift1994? I hit the door with my handlebar, and did an endo, and hit the ground with my head. I had no helmet on (which was unusual for me) and I could have died. It was my first broken bone, and it was a total fracture. The two ends of the bone moved, and I could push them around. They don\'t set collarbones: they just put a canvas band shaped like a figure 8 across your back, and cinch it tight. That keeps the shoulders spread out. It hurt like hell, and for a week, I was dizzy from endorphines, then later, from codeine. After another week, the codeine wasn\'t working anymore, so I quit it, and it hurt even more. There\'s still a bump on the collarbone from this fracture.

properties.name: Guero
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI guess the owner of this truck is pale or blonde. I don\'t know how good it is, but, I see it there.

properties.name: Hatchback veers off, hits median
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThis must have been around 1998 or so. I\'m driving north on the 110, and it\'s pretty late. This hatchback far in front of me is drifting left and right, just a little too much, and is driving pretty slow, so I\'m coming up on them. Figure it\'s a drunk driver, and I start looking for an exit so I can just take surface streets home. Within a few seconds, the car swerves leftward into the median, and bang, hits the median at maybe 40 mph. It was sickening. I flew right past it within a second or so, because i was coming up on the car fast. In my rear view, I saw the engine compartment catch fire, and vanish into the darkness. I tried to find an offramp; it was kind of far, and I got off. I was going to go back, but talked myself out of it. What could I do? I didn\'t have a cel phone or anything. I still feel bad about doing that.

properties.name: Home of Peace, Beth David Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift

properties.name: Human Quadriplegic Corpse on Display
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThe City of Whittier is strange. For some reason, they purchased a plasticized corpse of a man who was a quadriplegic, with his organs complete, but visible, and put it under glass on public display. It\'s gruesome, and has a faintly racist whiff to it. I don\'t know what it means to treat people who are disabled unfairly, but this seems to be very unfair, that this person is on display as some kind of entertainment. In addition to the body, there\'s a gift shop attached that sells t-shirts and other trashy souveniers. The corpse is located behind the TGI Sundays restaurant.

properties.name: Hydroplaned on the freeway
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI was headed to an interview, but it had been pretty rainy, and the 110 freeway tends to get these puddles here and there, due to poor drainage. The freeway also winds left and right, like a slalom track. (People like it.) So, I\'m driving down it, and hit a big wet area, and start skidding. I think I\'m gainng control, but hit water again, and spin the car into the railing in the middle, smashing my front bumper and my rear bumper. The car was steaming, but it was still running, so drove off the freeway in once piece. I\'m lucky that i didn\'t flip the car. I\'m also lucky that traffic on the 110 tends to clump behind slow cars, so there wasn\'t anyone behind me. The people behind me saw me spinning out, slowed down, and waited for me to clear out. The car was totalled. Ever since that accident, I have driven at or near the speed limit on the freeway.

properties.name: I jammed my finger while I was cutting away at a bolt...
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI just had the hacksaw and was cutting away at a bolt to dismantle a large garden wall. My finger was out or something, and I just slammed it. It hurt, but not that much. Eventually, within a couple weeks, it was swollen, and turning purple. I had to get it checked out, and all that. It wasn\'t broken, just injured. The end wasn\'t that, though. Less than a year later, it flared up during a gout attack; maybe it\'ll never totally heal up. 2006.

properties.name: I was at home, having just woken up...
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI\'d just moved back into my parents\' home, to help out since my father had a stroke several months prior. The first tower had been hit, and within a few minutes, the second had been as well. Despite his inability to speak, or even really reason at the time, my father knew it was bad.

properties.name: J&S
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftExcellent B&C with good beans. I think they use lard to make these beans. Low price. Right now, it\'s my favorite stand. Their other burritos are less great. The Chile Relleno is a little too eggy. The Green Chile is good, and the cooked down peppers are better than a sauce. The Tostada burrito is basically like the Del Taco Veggie Works, but a little better. Most people seem to come here for the taquitos, and get 2 or 3 orders.

properties.name: Jim's
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftIt\'s hit or miss. Beans are so-so, probably canned, but the cheese is melted.

properties.name: Jim's
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI think it\'s an eastside institution or something. There\'s more Jim\'s Burgers in some cities than there are McDonald\'s. I think Rosemead has three of them, and only 2 McDs. You see them in East LA, in Downtown, all over the SGV, in the IE, and even down in Corona. This one is a little different because it has a blue awning.

properties.name: Karina's Tacos
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift2025 Durfee Ave South El Monte, CA 91733 A good burrito with decent beans and a good flavor, but the whole thing is pretty small, and at 2.50, expensive for the size. They grill the tortilla, which is a big plus for me, because that\'s how I do it at home.

properties.name: King Taco
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift Everyone goes here, it seems.

properties.name: King Taco
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI don\'t go to KT much, for whatever reason. It\'s kind of expensive compared, and it\'s hit or miss on the quality. The B&C was okay - I asked for the onions, cilantro, and salsa, and that was a mistake, because those ingredients cooled down the cheese. The beans weren\'t hot enough to melt the mass. KT uses good ingredients; their tortilla is nice and soft, and tastes good. Their beans are so-so, but not canned. The ingredients tend to compensate for a burrito with too little bean, a little too much other stuff, and kind of small overall considering it\'s .25. Their red salsa tastes really good. It\'s hot, so get it on the side. Their chips suck though. Stay away.

properties.name: La Abeja
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftLittle restaurant with a cool new set of murals on the outside.

properties.name: Lucy's
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI don\'t know the location, but my boss brought me food from here. It was really good. The beans were nice and smooth, and there were more beans than cheese. The cheese was good and strong too.

properties.name: MacArthur Park sung by Richard Harris
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftSong written by Jimmy Webb. The song has been covered more than fifty times, including versions by Waylon Jennings, The Negro Problem, Glen Campbell, Maynard Ferguson, Stan Kenton, Sammy Davis, Jr. and Liza Minnelli. A disco version by Donna Summer in 1978 topped the U.S. charts for three weeks and ran to 8:40 in its full-length album version as part of "MacArthur Park suite" on Summer\'s 1978 double album "Live and More". Her first Billboard Hot 100 number one single in the United States was shorter. Summer also released the 17:40 long medley "MacArthur Park Suite" as a US 12" promo, incorporating the songs "One of a Kind" and "Heaven Knows". The suite went to number one on the Billboard Hot Dance Club Play chart for five weeks in 1978.

properties.name: Macy Intermediate Washroom
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftIt\'s old school: they have the tall urinals. At least they\'re tall to 11-year-olds.

properties.name: Molcasalsa at the Montebello Town Center food court
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift I asked for a bean burrito with a little cheese, and that is what I got. They do a good job overall, and the beans are pretty good. There were a few sub-creamy beans, but overall, it was a good batch. They also grill the tortilla, so it\'s flaky. That\'s a new thing I\'m starting to notice, and like. The best part is the price of .50, which, for this mall, is a really good deal. For some reason, most of the food court stands are kind of expensive and mediocre. (I found a blog post about a related shop in La Habra. The food is kind of similar.) If you\'re a vegetarian, the neighboring booth, Massis Kabob, has falafel.

properties.name: Mt. Sinai Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift

properties.name: Odd Fellows Cemetary
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftPlan to visit this one at some time.

properties.name: Official Meeting House of The Kings x93x
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThis is the last known location of The Kings street gang\'s meeting house. The Kings, aka Breakfast Kings, aka Burger Kings, aka the Not-Have-Nots are notorious for controlling the Heights with an iron fist (and lots of small caliber ammo) and for extorting the local residents for "taxes" to pay for "security" from the rival gangs (especially the rivals in the flats, the Little Kings, aka Lunch Kings, aka Dairy Queens). Also, the gangs are rivals in the real estate business. Be careful. Better yet, stay away.

properties.name: Old Chinese Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThe old Chinese cemetery was under this site, but was moved.

properties.name: Original Location of the Santa Fe Metalworks
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftAs part of its vertically integrated trust, Santa Fe Railroad owned a number of metalworks. At this location was a spring factory that twisted steel wire into large springs for use on boxcars. Eventually, the rail trust was broken up into separate companies, but, the board members still got along well, and it was just as if they were still a monopolistic combine most of the time. When the city incorporated, the railroad was still powerful in the city, and strongarmed the city fathers into naming it "Santa Fe Springs." The boardmembers thought it was a good joke. (By this time, the company had been renamed to "Universal Spring Company" and had begun to specialize in making springs for garage doors.)

properties.name: Original location of Bell's Garden
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftIn 1924, Phineas Bell, a poor landscaper, began planting his personal garden on a piece of land that wasn\'t his. The soil was rich with the loam from the meandering river, and the garden flourished, eventually occupying both county property and part of a private ranch. Because he did all his gardening at night, the property owners were scarcely aware what was going on. By 1927, the gardens were over eight acres of wildflowers, young saplings, and squash vines. A pond had developed, and in it lived a strange fish that glowed in the dark. Shortly after the stock market crash of 1929, Bell passed on due to poor health and lack of work, but his garden grew wild, and expanded itself. It wasn\'t until the Great Depression, when itinerant "okie" workers on the rails were looking for places to camp out, that the garden was discovered. Rather, they discovered it, but kept it a secret, to keep the vegetables for themselves. One of the migrant workers, coincidentally named Bell as well,l was entrepreneurial, and gathered up the vegetables and opened a roadside stand. The vegetables were good, and the stand did well through the Depression. WW2 came, and the owner used his social standing to coordinate Victory Gardens for the war effort. After the war, he resumed his grocery business, but quickly shifted strategy to become one of the first supermarkets in Southern California. (By this time, of course, the gardens were no longer occupied, but still grew many vegetables wild.) Having amassed great wealth, Bell purchased the old garden area, both the county and ranch portion. He took the ranch portion and subdivided it into 1/4 acre lots, for suburban development. Then, he took the remainder and converted it into a small 9-hole golf-course. A decade later, he bribed three members of the city council into approving a plan to expanding the 9-holes into a 18-hole public golf course, at public expense. More recently, the original ranch subdivisions have voted to erect a wall around itself, creating a new gated community named "Bell\'s Country Club Village."

properties.name: Peace Sign, switch to satellite view and zoom in.
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftIf you switch to satellite view and zoom in here, you will see a large Peace sign in the dirt.

properties.name: Pepe's
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftAn old stand with a drive through!

properties.name: Porky's
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftA pork themed restaurant.

properties.name: Rear ended my new car!
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI was just sitting there in my new, six month old truck, and a dude in his company delivery car hits me. It bent my bumper. I just took the insurance money and spent it on myself. It\'s a truck, and it\'s not really a truck until it gets dented or scratched.

properties.name: Remnants of a wreck
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI didn\'t see the wreck, but saw the glass and broken plastic in the intersection. In the debris, I found a marijuana cigarette, completely unsmoked, and probably ditched by the occupants of one of the vehicles.

properties.name: Resurrection Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftA Catholic cemetery

properties.name: Rick's Burgers
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftLocal burger shack chain. Has a nice outdoor seating patio, where they sometimes have music.

properties.name: Riding my yellow bike with training wheels...
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift my toe got caught in between the chain and the front gear. It went in just a little, but the toe was little at the time, too, and I was in slippers, so it was pretty deep. Notably, this bicycle lacked a coaster brake, so forward momentum caused the pedals to roll forward (like a tricycle). 1974?

properties.name: Roger Mahoney's Church
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift(Not the current archbishop Mahoney.) This is the original site of the Church of the Firestone, founded by Roger Mahoney in 1890. This is not *the* Roger Mahoney, but a different person. Mahoney was an Irish-Catholic immigrant who founded a pagan cult that worshipped fire. As a sacrament, they consumed small amounts of flint and practiced flint-based rituals to summon the god of fire. Every Friday night (which they called Fire-Day night), Mahoney would evangelize the local migrant workers about the sun, fire, light, warmth, or hell. Afterward, the parishoners would have a ritual cooking of meat on the barbeque, and would eat together. Though most of the members didn\'t really believe in what Mahoney said, they stayed for the excellent grilled meats. The flint was collected from a small mine located around half a mile from this site, to the south. Over time, the flint mine operations became lucrative enough to sustain the church in relative opulence. Mahoney became enamoured of creating spectacular fireshows during his sermons, using large metal pans of kerosene and alcohol, giving his church an exciting advatage over the rival Methodist and Episocopal churches. Roger Mahoney eventually had some members create a chrome plated, propane flamethrower that would, on command, shoot long streams of blue and yellow flames above the pews. The members were ecstatic, and the church grew, especially during the early parts of the Great Depression, when meat was expensive, Mahoney was rich, and the BBQ was plentiful. It all ended when, one night, someone forgot to close the propane valve completely, and the next morning\'s sermon resulted in the entire front of the church exploding into flames, killing fifteen people, including Mahoney. Remaining members re-established the church in La Canada.

properties.name: Rose Hills
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThe cemetery that advertises itself with a red neon sign reading ROSE HILLS, visible for miles. It\'s like the HOLLYWOOD or the JESUS SAVES sign, except for the dead.

properties.name: Russian Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI don\'t know much about this, but check this out: http://www.lalc.k12.ca.us/access/people/molokans/

properties.name: San Gabriel Mission
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThere are some folks buried here.

properties.name: Sandpaper Books
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftAbrasive texts. Situationist and art books, mostly.

properties.name: Santa Monica by Everclear
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThey didn\'t mention it specifically, but they did title their song after the city, and captured some of the city\'s depressing vibe correctly. With my big black boots and an old suitcase I do believe Ill find myself a new place I dont want to be the bad guy I dont want to do your sleepwalk dance anymore I just want to see some palm trees Go and try and shake away this disease

properties.name: Savannah Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftNamed for Savannah Georgia. The owner of the area was from there.

properties.name: Serbian Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift

properties.name: Smelled Good
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI don\'t eat meat, but my girlfriend does, and did eat some birria from this truck. It smelled great, and the little nibble I tasted confirmed that it was good. Truck is there only at night. Blue signage, religious mural on side.

properties.name: Some Truck
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI took a risk on some truck that parked here. They didn\'t know what a B&C was. I had to explain it, then try again in really bad Spanish. They concluded I meant vegetarian, and proceeded to make a B&C with onions, lettuce, and sauce. Oh well. It was pretty good for a truck. The onions are good to add.

properties.name: Stabbed my hand while pitting an avocado.
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift1990? Lacking a sharp knife to cut into the pit of the avocado, I used the sharp point of a dull knife, pointing straight down. The knife hit the pit, split it in two, and the point went into my hand. Went to the hospital and had it sewn up. You could see the fat and muscle under the skin.

properties.name: Summertime by Sublime
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftSublime, America\'s favorite wig-drunk-punk-ska/reggae/hip-hop band, said they were "well qualified to represent the L.B.C." Who are we to dispute.

properties.name: Super Burrito
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift3631 colorado, pasadena, caThis shack had a major build up in the local press for years, and they tacked one of the articles up on the wall. I got the chile relleno burrito, because I was very hungry. Unfortunately, it wasn\'t that good. It was okay, but, a little on the cold side. The cheese wasn\'t in the proper, runny, molten state. Pasadena food is mediocre. Long-standing, mediocre restaurants, combined with a loyal, indiscriminate clientele, and high startup costs, assure that new competition will have a hard time getting established. Corporations take note: ignore the local\'s stated aversion to chain products - because that\'s what they will take. Just relabel it to deceive them.

properties.name: Taco Kingdom
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftIt\'s true what they say about the peasant diet in feudal monarchies: the food is not very good. I had to wonder, is King Taco the monarch of this Kingdom, or is this the domain of another? The B&C had a pretty good texture, but the flavor was off. It was pasty, not creamy. The cheese was not fully melted, but the combination was fine. They provide a much needed container of sauce, which makes the burrito taste more like a taco. Maybe what this kingdom needs is a Magna Carta of beans, a more democratic system where the eaters can tell the rulers how to make the beans. Power to the people.

properties.name: Taco Nazo
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftTaco Nazo moved from the mall across the street, ending the quirky phenomenon of a taco shop located in an Asian mall that looked like a huge Buddhist temple. Taco Nazo specializes in fish tacos, but I got a B&C. White cheese, as is the new tradition out here, and a little pricey, but it was a big one. The cheese wasn\'t overpowering, either, just the way I like it. It was runny, which is a plus for me, for some reason. They also provide these baked chiles with salt and pepper, for free, and they probably helped boost the overall experience. (Their fish tacos are really good, too.) The only downside is that it\'s for a B&C. Kinda pricey. (I think I may have made an error with the location on the map.)

properties.name: Taco Ready
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift8404 Garvey Ave, Rosemead, CASeems to have improved over time. Beans were a little on the salty side, but nice and drippy the way I like it. Lots of cheese, good salsa, and I can add onion. BIG!

properties.name: Tacos El Gavilan
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftYou should go here once just because it looks like an old McDonalds. The B&C is the new Mexican style, and was good enough that I wolfed it down. Check out the linked article. It\'s funny.

properties.name: Tacos Mexico at the Puente Hills Mall
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift The B&C here is a vague memory at best. All I remember was saying that it was surprisingly good, because the few Tacos Mexicos I\'ve eaten at, when I was eating meat, were lousy. If you\'re stuck at this mall, there\'s not a lot of options, anyway.

properties.name: Tacos Oaxaca (a truck)
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftDo they even like tacos in Oaxaca? The first B&C they did for me was not very good, and I panned them on this map - cold cheese, too-hard beans, lots of onions. A few tries later, however, they have really upped the quality, and their mix of bean and cheese is much better, plus they go easy on the onions. They use whole beans that are nice and soft, and a white cheese. Their meat tacos are also very good.

properties.name: The most gruesome one ever
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftI\'m driving westward, but on the eastward side, I see a green compact car, crushed laterally against the concrete median, sandwiched between a large semi truck trailer and the median. I see nothing. It\'s all coming from my imagination. I feel ill for a while.

properties.name: Tongva Cemetery Location (former?)
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift

properties.name: Top's Jr.
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThis burrito has a surprise: potatoes. The overall mix is pretty good, but not great. The potatoes have been over-salted, and lack the puffiness that makes for great potatoes. Still, it\'s a nice surprise. The beans are okay, but not that special. Just barely okay at that. They just get a boost for trying the potatoes.

properties.name: Troy's
properties.description: Posted by Wildgift Typical L.A. burger shack. Burgers, Mexican food, dinners. The B&C here is really good, but the bill for a burrito, fries, and a soda was ! The beans were just right, and the cheese was melted and not overwhelming.

properties.name: Vegetarian Burrito
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThis isn\'t a B&C. Their idea of vegetarian is to add salsa and shredded cabbage or lettuce into the burrito. It tastes okay. Go for the yellow chilis.

properties.name: Ventura Blvd. from Free Falling and Valley Girl
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftThis street was mentioned in Tom Petty\'s "Free Falling," as well as in Frank Zappa\'s "Valley Girl."

properties.name: While moving a bookcase, I slipped...
properties.description: Posted by Wildgiftdown the stairs. The bookcase kind of slid to one side, and I to the other, scraping my elbow on the stucco. It isn\'t a real injury, but it did go in there pretty far, and my arm was dripping blood for a while. 2006.

properties.name: Xris
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftAccording to Angelo, this is a Jim\'s that got converted to a clean restaurant that serves healthy (as well as unhealthy) food.

properties.name: Yeah, Right, Friendly
properties.description: Posted by WildgiftOne of the few golf courses maintained by the strange Phineas Bell, this club, for many years, excluded Africans, Jews, Italians, Catholics, Finns, Japanese, Chinese, Portuguese, Amer Indians, West Indians, East Indians, Quebecois, Arabs, Cajuns, and Greeks. Koreans were allowed, because one of the founders was a Korean. It\'s ironic (if you can call it that) that Arabs were excluded, because one of the founders and original investors was Osama "Sammy" Davis, Sr. who was half Arab and half Scot, but not a golfer (amazingly enough). Davis was the father of the jazz trombonist Sameer "Sammy" Davis, Jr. who would eventually convert to Judaism, and learn to play golf as part of his cultural study prior to conversion.
